OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose a patient presenting with chronic headaches, fatigue, and weight loss.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient reports a 3-month history of persistent, dull, generalized headaches. She describes them as being present most days, often worse in the mornings and exacerbated by standing up quickly. Over-the-counter analgesics provide minimal relief. Alongside the headaches, she has experienced profound fatigue, unintentional weight loss of approximately 5kg over the past 4 months despite a normal appetite initially, and intermittent nausea. She mentions recently developing a craving for salty foods like crisps and pickles. Her husband commented that her skin looks 'more tanned' than usual, even though she hasn't had significant sun exposure.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Vitiligo diagnosed 5 years ago. No history of tuberculosis, major surgeries, or chronic medication use, specifically no history of steroid therapy. Up-to-date with routine immunizations.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Works as a primary school teacher. Non-smoker, drinks 1-2 glasses of wine on weekends. Reports moderate work-related stress. Lives with her husband and two children.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Confirms progressive fatigue, weakness, weight loss, nausea, and headaches. Notes increased skin pigmentation and salt craving. Denies fever, chills, night sweats, cough, chest pain, palpitations (other than occasional racing heart on standing). No vomiting or diarrhea. Denies abdominal pain beyond mild nausea. Denies urinary symptoms. Menstrual cycles have become irregular (oligomenorrhea) over the past 6 months. Denies visual disturbances (blurring, diplopia), focal weakness or numbness, seizures, or history of syncope. No history of recent trauma. No new medications.

Vital_Signs.Blood_Pressure: 100/65 mmHg (supine), 85/55 mmHg (standing, with patient reporting dizziness)

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Appears tired and mildly cachectic. Alert and oriented x3.

Skin_Examination.Inspection: Diffuse hyperpigmentation, particularly noticeable in palmar creases, buccal mucosa (bluish-black patches), nipples, and over recent scars (e.g., a small scratch on forearm is darkly pigmented). Patches of depigmentation consistent with vitiligo present on dorsal aspects of hands and around the mouth. Mucous membranes appear slightly dry.

Head_Neck_ENT_Examination.Head: Normocephalic, atraumatic.
Head_Neck_ENT_Examination.Eyes: PERRLA, EOMI. Conjunctivae pink. No scleral icterus. Fundoscopy: Optic discs sharp, no papilledema.
Head_Neck_ENT_Examination.ENT: Oral mucosa shows hyperpigmentation. Pharynx clear. No lymphadenopathy.

Cardiovascular_Examination.Inspection: No visible jugular venous distension at 45 degrees.
Cardiovascular_Examination.Palpation: Apex beat not displaced. No heaves or thrills.
Cardiovascular_Examination.Auscultation: S1, S2 normal. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops.

Respiratory_Examination.Auscultation: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes or crackles.

Abdominal_Examination.Inspection: Abdomen flat, symmetrical. No visible scars (other than small, hyperpigmented old ones), striae, or distension.
Abdominal_Examination.Palpation: Soft, non-tender. No hepatosplenomegaly or masses palpated.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert, oriented, appropriate mood and affect.
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: II-XII intact. Visual fields full to confrontation.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Mild generalized weakness (4+/5 power globally), more pronounced proximally. Normal tone. No focal deficits. No tremor or involuntary movements.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception throughout.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes 2+ and symmetrical. Plantars downgoing bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Function: Finger-nose-finger and heel-to-shin tests performed adequately, though some slowness due to generalized weakness. Gait slightly unsteady, especially on turning, but no frank ataxia.

Complete_Blood_Count.Differential: Neutrophils 50%, Lymphocytes 35%, Monocytes 8%, Eosinophils 7% (Normal: 1-4%) - Mild eosinophilia

Hormonal_Assays.Morning_Cortisol_8AM: 65 nmol/L (Reference range for 8 AM: 170-540 nmol/L) - Markedly Low
Hormonal_Assays.Plasma_ACTH_8AM: 720 pg/mL (Reference range for 8 AM: <46 pg/mL) - Markedly High
Hormonal_Assays.ACTH_Stimulation_Test_Short_Synacthen: Baseline cortisol: 60 nmol/L. 30-min post-250mcg Synacthen: 70 nmol/L. 60-min post-Synacthen: 75 nmol/L. (Interpretation: Subnormal response; peak cortisol <500 nmol/L and increment <200 nmol/L)

CT_Brain_with_and_without_contrast.Reason_for_exam: Persistent headaches, rule out intracranial pathology.
CT_Brain_with_and_without_contrast.Findings: No evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage, mass lesion, hydrocephalus, or signs of raised intracranial pressure. Normal attenuation of brain parenchyma. No abnormal enhancement.

ECG.Findings: Sinus rhythm, rate 85 bpm. PR interval normal, QRS duration normal. Peaked T waves noted in leads V2-V5, consistent with hyperkalemia. No acute ST-T wave changes suggestive of ischemia.

Abdominal_CT_scan_adrenal_protocol.Reason_for_exam: Evaluation of adrenal glands given hormonal findings.
Abdominal_CT_scan_adrenal_protocol.Findings: Bilateral adrenal gland atrophy. No evidence of adrenal hemorrhage, calcification, or neoplastic masses. Other visualized abdominal organs appear unremarkable.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Addison Disease (Primary Adrenal Insufficiency) due to autoimmune adrenalitis

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose a patient presenting with chronic headaches, fatigue, and dizziness, considering anaemia as a differential diagnosis.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 3-month history of persistent, dull, generalised headaches, occurring almost daily. She describes the headache as worse towards the end of the day and exacerbated by physical activity. She also reports significant fatigue, feeling tired 'all the time', and episodes of dizziness, especially on standing up. She has noticed increasing shortness of breath when climbing stairs and occasional palpitations. She mentions her periods have been heavier than usual for the past 6-9 months. She has been a vegetarian for 10 years. She denies any recent trauma, fever, visual disturbances, or focal neurological symptoms.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No significant chronic illnesses. No previous surgeries. One previous pregnancy 3 years ago, uncomplicated, but was told she had 'borderline low iron' at the time.
Medications: Occasional ibuprofen for headaches (2-3 times a week)
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Vegetarian for 10 years, tries to eat a balanced diet but admits to sometimes skipping meals due to a busy schedule as a primary school teacher. Non-smoker. Drinks 1-2 glasses of wine on weekends. Denies illicit drug use.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: General: Significant fatigue, feels generally unwell. Reports looking paler than usual. No significant weight loss. Cardiovascular: Palpitations on exertion, exertional dyspnoea. No chest pain, orthopnoea, or PND. Respiratory: No cough, wheeze, or haemoptysis. GI: Good appetite. No abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, constipation, melaena, or haematochezia. Reports occasional craving for ice (pagophagia). GU: Menorrhagia for 6-9 months (soaking through pads every 2-3 hours on heaviest days, passing clots). No dysuria or haematuria. Neurological: Headaches as described. Dizziness. No seizures, syncope, weakness, numbness, or visual changes. Reports restless sensations in her legs at night. Musculoskeletal: No joint pain or swelling. Skin: No rashes or easy bruising.

General_Examination.Lymph_Nodes: No cervical, axillary, or inguinal lymphadenopathy.

Cardiovascular_Examination.Heart_Sounds: S1, S2 normal. Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur heard best at the left sternal edge, does not radiate.

Respiratory_Examination.Auscultation: Clear breath sounds bilaterally, no added sounds.

Abdominal_Examination.Palpation: Soft, non-tender. No hepatosplenomegaly. No masses palpated.

Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: II-XII intact. Fundoscopy: Optic discs sharp, no papilloedema, normal vasculature.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Normal tone, power (5/5) in all limbs. No pronator drift.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes ++ bilaterally, symmetrical. Plantars downgoing.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception.
Neurological_Examination.Meningeal_Signs: No neck stiffness. Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs negative.

Peripheral_Blood_Smear.Findings: Microcytic, hypochromic red blood cells. Anisocytosis and poikilocytosis present. Occasional pencil cells.

CT_Brain_Non_Contrast.Findings: No acute intracranial hemorrhage, mass effect, or evidence of hydrocephalus. Grey-white matter differentiation preserved. Ventricles and sulci are normal for age. No signs of cerebral venous sinus thrombosis.

ECG.Findings: Sinus tachycardia at 98 bpm. Normal axis. No ST-T wave changes suggestive of ischaemia. Normal intervals.

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess, investigate, and diagnose a patient presenting with persistent headaches and new-onset visual disturbances.

Patient_Actor.History: Ms. Smith presents with a 6-week history of progressively worsening headaches. Initially, she experienced them 2-3 times a week, but they are now near-daily. She describes the headache as global, dull to throbbing in nature, typically worse in the mornings and exacerbated by coughing or bending forward. Over-the-counter analgesics like paracetamol and ibuprofen provide minimal relief. Over the past 2 weeks, she has also noticed brief episodes where her vision 'greys out' for a few seconds, especially when standing up quickly from a seated position. She also reports occasional horizontal double vision, particularly when looking to her far left. She mentions a 'whooshing' sound in her right ear, synchronous with her heartbeat, which is more noticeable in quiet environments. She denies any recent head trauma or febrile illness.

Secondary_Symptoms: Horizontal diplopia on left lateral gaze

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Acne vulgaris, diagnosed 1 year ago. Otherwise healthy. No history of migraines, seizures, or neurological disorders. No previous surgeries.
Medications: Minocycline 100mg daily, started 3 months ago for acne
Combined oral contraceptive pill (ethinylestradiol/levonorgestrel), ongoing for 5 years
Patient_Actor.Family_History: Mother has a history of migraines. Father has hypertension. No family history of neurological diseases or brain tumors.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Works as a graphic designer, involves significant screen time. Non-smoker. Drinks 2-3 units of alcohol per week. Denies illicit drug use. Lives with her partner.

Review_of_Systems.General: Reports some fatigue, attributes it to poor sleep due to headaches. Recent weight gain of 3 kg over the past 4 months.
Review_of_Systems.Neurological: No focal weakness, no sensory loss (paraesthesia or numbness), no speech disturbance, no gait imbalance, no vertigo, no seizures. Denies photophobia or phonophobia. Denies neck stiffness.
Review_of_Systems.HEENT: Besides visual symptoms and tinnitus, denies earache, sore throat, nasal discharge, or sinus pain.
Review_of_Systems.Cardiovascular: No chest pain, palpitations, or orthopnea.
Review_of_Systems.Respiratory: No cough, shortness of breath, or wheezing.
Review_of_Systems.Gastrointestinal: Mild nausea as mentioned, no vomiting, no change in bowel habits, no abdominal pain.
Review_of_Systems.Genitourinary: Denies dysuria or changes in urinary frequency.
Review_of_Systems.Musculoskeletal: No joint pain or muscle weakness.
Review_of_Systems.Dermatological: Acne on face and back. No new rashes.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Appears uncomfortable due to headache but not in acute distress. Well-nourished.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Glasgow Coma Scale 15/15. Speech is clear and fluent. Cognition grossly intact.

Cranial_Nerves_Detailed.CN_II: Visual acuity (Snellen chart): Right 6/9, Left 6/9 (patient reports baseline is 6/6). Pupils equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation (PERRLA). Fundoscopy: Bilateral optic disc swelling with blurring of disc margins, venous engorgement, and loss of optic cup, consistent with papilledema (Frisén grade II-III). Visual fields: Full to confrontation, but patient reports some peripheral blurriness on the left.
Cranial_Nerves_Detailed.CN_III_IV_VI: Eye movements: Full range of movements in the right eye. Left eye shows mild limitation of abduction. Horizontal diplopia reported on left lateral gaze. No ptosis. No nystagmus.
Cranial_Nerves_Detailed.CN_V: Facial sensation intact in all three divisions bilaterally. Motor function (muscles of mastication) normal.
Cranial_Nerves_Detailed.CN_VIII: Hearing grossly intact to whispered voice bilaterally (audiometry pending for tinnitus).
Cranial_Nerves_Detailed.CN_IX_X: Palate elevates symmetrically, gag reflex present.
Cranial_Nerves_Detailed.CN_XI: Shoulder shrug and head turn against resistance normal.

Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Normal muscle bulk, tone, and power (5/5) in all four limbs.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception in all four limbs.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes 2+ and symmetrical throughout. Plantar responses downgoing bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Tests: Finger-nose test, heel-shin test, and rapid alternating movements are performed well. No dysmetria or dysdiadochokinesia.
Neurological_Examination.Gait: Normal gait, able to tandem walk.
Neurological_Examination.Meningeal_Signs: No neck stiffness. Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs negative.

Other_Examination.Cardiovascular: Normal S1, S2, no murmurs or added sounds.
Other_Examination.Respiratory: Chest clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles.
Other_Examination.Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, no organomegaly. Bowel sounds normal.

CT_Brain_Non_Contrast.Findings: No evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage, mass lesion, hydrocephalus, or overt sinus pathology. Ventricular size normal.

MRI_Brain_and_MR_Venography.MRI_Brain_Findings: Normal brain parenchyma. No mass lesion, infarction, or hydrocephalus. Partially empty sella noted. Optic nerve sheaths appear mildly distended bilaterally. Subtle flattening of the posterior sclera. No abnormal enhancement.
MRI_Brain_and_MR_Venography.MR_Venography_Findings: Patent dural venous sinuses. No evidence of cerebral venous sinus thrombosis. Possible mild bilateral transverse sinus stenosis.

Lumbar_Puncture.Opening_Pressure: 35 cmH2O (Elevated; Normal range up to 25 cmH2O in adults)

CSF_Analysis.Glucose: 3.5 mmol/L (Normal, with concurrent serum glucose of 5.5 mmol/L)

Ophthalmology_Consultation_Findings.Fundoscopy: Confirmed bilateral papilledema, Frisén grade II-III.
Ophthalmology_Consultation_Findings.Formal_Visual_Field_Testing_Perimetry: Enlarged blind spots bilaterally. Mild inferonasal visual field defect in the left eye.
Ophthalmology_Consultation_Findings.Optical_Coherence_Tomography_OCT: Increased retinal nerve fiber layer (RNFL) thickness bilaterally, consistent with optic disc edema.

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose a patient presenting with acute severe unilateral headache, neck pain, and transient neurological symptoms.

Patient_Actor.History: Patient presents with a 2-day history of sudden onset, severe, left-sided headache and neck pain. The pain began abruptly while she was performing a strenuous neck-twisting movement during an advanced yoga class. The headache is described as constant, throbbing, 8/10 in severity, radiating from the left side of her neck up to her left temple and behind her left eye. Yesterday, she experienced an episode of slurred speech and clumsiness in her right hand that lasted approximately 15 minutes and then fully resolved. Her husband also noticed that her left eyelid appeared 'droopy' and her left pupil looked 'smaller' than the right since yesterday.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Sudden onset severe left-sided headache and neck pain
Secondary_Symptoms: Pain radiating from neck to left temple/eye

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: History of occasional mild tension headaches, typically bilateral and responsive to over-the-counter analgesics. No history of migraines, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, connective tissue disease, or clotting disorders. No previous surgeries.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Non-smoker. Consumes 2-3 units of alcohol on weekends. Actively participates in strenuous yoga classes three times a week; recently started incorporating more advanced poses involving significant neck movement.
Patient_Actor.Medications: None regularly. Takes ibuprofen 400mg as needed for occasional tension headaches (tried for current headache with no relief). No known drug allergies.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies fever, chills, night sweats. Denies overt visual loss (other than noted eyelid droop), photophobia, or phonophobia. No nausea or vomiting. No preceding aura. Denies rash, joint pain, or unexplained weight loss. No chest pain, palpitations, or shortness of breath. No abdominal pain, changes in bowel or bladder habits. Initially denied recent specific trauma, but on further questioning about neck movements, she recalled the new yoga pose two days prior involving a forceful neck turn that felt 'unusually strenuous' and immediately preceded the onset of pain.

General_Examination.Appearance: Alert, oriented to person, place, and time. Appears uncomfortable due to headache. Well-nourished.

HEENT_Examination.Head: Normocephalic, atraumatic.
HEENT_Examination.Eyes: Partial ptosis of the left eyelid. Anisocoria with left pupil (2mm) smaller than right pupil (4mm); both reactive to light and accommodation. Extraocular movements intact. Visual fields full to confrontation. Fundoscopy reveals sharp optic discs bilaterally, no papilledema, hemorrhages, or exudates.
HEENT_Examination.Throat: Oropharynx clear, no erythema or exudate.
HEENT_Examination.Neck: Supple. Mild tenderness to palpation over the left anterior cervical region, anterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle. No palpable lymphadenopathy or thyroid masses. No carotid bruits auscultated. No nuchal rigidity.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert, oriented x3, language fluent, attention intact.
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: CN I not tested. CN II-XII: As noted above, left-sided ptosis and miosis (consistent with Horner's syndrome). Facial sensation and movement symmetrical. Tongue midline, palate elevates symmetrically. Shoulder shrug and head turn normal strength.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Normal bulk and tone. Power 5/5 in all four limbs. No pronator drift.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception throughout.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes 2+ and symmetrical in upper and lower extremities. Plantar responses downgoing bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Function: Finger-nose-finger and heel-to-shin tests performed well. No dysmetria.
Neurological_Examination.Gait: Normal gait, able to tandem walk.

Cardiovascular_Examination.Palpation: Apical impulse not displaced. No heaves or thrills.
Cardiovascular_Examination.Auscultation: S1 and S2 normal. Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops.

Respiratory_Examination.Inspection: Symmetrical chest expansion, no use of accessory muscles.
Respiratory_Examination.Auscultation: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.

Blood_Tests.Complete_Blood_Count: Hb 13.5 g/dL, WBC 7.2 x10^9/L (Neutrophils 60%, Lymphocytes 30%), Platelets 250 x10^9/L
Blood_Tests.Urea_And_Electrolytes: Sodium 140 mmol/L, Potassium 4.2 mmol/L, Urea 5.0 mmol/L

CT_Brain_Non_Contrast.Findings: No acute intracranial hemorrhage, mass effect, hydrocephalus, or large territory ischemic stroke identified. Grey-white matter differentiation preserved. Age-appropriate appearances.

CT_Angiogram_Head_And_Neck.Findings: Diagnostic quality study. Reveals evidence of dissection of the left internal carotid artery, commencing approximately 2.1 cm distal to the carotid bifurcation and extending superiorly into the petrous segment. An intimal flap is visualized with associated mural hematoma, causing moderate (approximately 60%) stenosis of the true lumen. No pseudoaneurysm identified. The right internal carotid artery, external carotid arteries, and vertebral arteries are patent and unremarkable. Normal intracranial vasculature without evidence of aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation.

ECG.Findings: Sinus rhythm, rate 76 bpm. Normal axis, intervals, and segments. No evidence of acute ischemia or arrhythmia.

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess a middle-aged male presenting with progressive headaches, nausea, and subtle neurological changes. Formulate a differential diagnosis, order appropriate investigations, and arrive at the correct diagnosis of a cerebral tumour.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 3-month history of progressively worsening headaches. Initially intermittent and mild, they are now near-constant, dull, and throbbing, predominantly bifrontal. Headaches are significantly worse in the mornings, often waking him from sleep, and are associated with nausea. He has vomited twice in the past week, only in the morning. He also reports increasing 'clumsiness' in his left hand for the past month, making tasks like writing and using tools difficult. His wife accompanies him and mentions he has become more irritable and forgetful over the last 2 months (e.g., misplacing items, forgetting conversations). He initially attributed these symptoms to stress from a demanding project at work.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Hypertension diagnosed 2 years ago, currently taking Lisinopril. No history of diabetes, previous cancers, migraines, or other neurological disorders. No previous surgeries. Vaccinations up to date.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Works as an architect, reports significant work-related stress over the past few months. Married, lives with wife, two adult children not living at home. Non-smoker. Consumes 1-2 glasses of wine on weekends. Denies illicit drug use. Exercises infrequently.

Review_of_Systems.General: Reports some fatigue. Denies fever, chills, night sweats, or unintentional weight loss.
Review_of_Systems.Neurological: Headache, nausea, vomiting, left hand clumsiness, irritability, and forgetfulness as described. Denies overt seizures, visual disturbances (blurring, diplopia, field loss - though papilledema is found on exam), tinnitus, vertigo, dysphagia, dysarthria (though subtle changes might be present), or syncope. Denies history of significant head trauma. Denies photophobia or phonophobia typically associated with migraines.
Review_of_Systems.Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain, palpitations, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.
Review_of_Systems.Respiratory: Denies cough, shortness of breath, hemoptysis.
Review_of_Systems.Gastrointestinal: Nausea and vomiting as described. Denies abdominal pain, diarrhea, constipation, jaundice, hematemesis, or melena.
Review_of_Systems.Musculoskeletal: Denies joint pain or swelling. Left hand clumsiness noted.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Appears tired but alert and cooperative. Well-nourished male. Slightly flat affect noted.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert and oriented to person, place, and time (GCS 15/15). Speech is clear. Mild difficulty with serial 7s. Recent memory seems mildly impaired based on wife's report and difficulty recalling details of symptom onset.
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: CN I: Not formally tested. CN II: Visual acuity 6/9 bilaterally with correction. Visual fields full to confrontation. Fundoscopy reveals bilateral papilledema with venous engorgement and blurred optic disc margins. CN III, IV, VI: Pupils 3mm, equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation. Extraocular movements intact, no nystagmus. CN V: Facial sensation intact to light touch and pinprick bilaterally. Masseter and temporalis power normal. CN VII: Facial movements symmetric, no weakness. CN VIII: Hearing grossly intact to whispered voice. Weber midline, Rinne AC>BC bilaterally. CN IX, X: Gag reflex present, uvula midline on phonation. CN XI: Sternocleidomastoid and trapezius power 5/5 bilaterally. CN XII: Tongue protrudes midline, no fasciculations.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Good muscle bulk bilaterally. Tone normal in right upper and lower limbs; slightly increased (spasticity) in left upper and lower limbs. Power: Right upper/lower limb 5/5. Left upper limb: Deltoid 4/5, Biceps 4+/5, Triceps 4+/5, Wrist extensors/flexors 4/5, Finger abductors/adductors 4/5. Left pronator drift present. Left lower limb: Hip flexion 4+/5, Knee extension/flexion 4+/5, Ankle dorsiflexion/plantarflexion 4+/5.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes: Biceps, Triceps, Brachioradialis, Patellar, Achilles +2 and symmetric on the right. Hyperreflexia (+3) on the left for all tested reflexes. Plantar response: Downgoing (flexor) on the right, upgoing (extensor - positive Babinski sign) on the left.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception in all four limbs. No sensory level.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Function: Finger-to-nose testing: Normal on the right; mild dysmetria on the left. Heel-to-shin testing: Normal on the right; mild ataxia on the left. Rapid alternating movements (dysdiadochokinesia) mildly impaired on the left.
Neurological_Examination.Gait_and_Coordination: Gait is slightly wide-based with reduced arm swing on the left. Mild circumduction of the left leg noted. Romberg test negative (able to stand with eyes closed, some sway).
Neurological_Examination.Meningeal_Signs: No nuchal rigidity. Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs negative.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Cardiovascular_Examination: Normal S1 and S2, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Carotid pulses normal, no bruits. Peripheral pulses palpable and symmetric.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Respiratory_Examination: Chest clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles. Normal respiratory effort.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Abdominal_Examination: Soft, non-tender, non-distended. Bowel sounds present and normal. No hepatosplenomegaly or palpable masses.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Skin_Examination: No rashes, petechiae, or suspicious lesions.

Blood_Tests.Full_Blood_Count: Hemoglobin 14.8 g/dL (Normal range: 13.5-17.5 g/dL), WBC 7.2 x 10^9/L (Normal range: 4.0-11.0 x 10^9/L), Platelets 260 x 10^9/L (Normal range: 150-400 x 10^9/L). Differential normal.
Blood_Tests.Renal_Panel_Urea_Electrolytes: Sodium 140 mmol/L (Normal range: 135-145 mmol/L), Potassium 4.1 mmol/L (Normal range: 3.5-5.0 mmol/L), Urea 5.2 mmol/L (Normal range: 2.5-7.8 mmol/L), Creatinine 85 µmol/L (Normal range: 60-110 µmol/L).
Blood_Tests.Liver_Function_Tests: ALT 28 U/L (Normal range: <40 U/L), AST 25 U/L (Normal range: <40 U/L), ALP 75 U/L (Normal range: 30-120 U/L), Total Bilirubin 12 µmol/L (Normal range: <21 µmol/L).
Blood_Tests.Inflammatory_Markers: CRP <5 mg/L (Normal range: <5 mg/L), ESR 12 mm/hr (Normal range: <15 mm/hr).

CT_Brain_without_and_with_contrast.Findings: Non-contrast CT demonstrates a poorly-defined area of low attenuation in the right fronto-parietal region, causing mass effect with effacement of the adjacent cortical sulci and the body of the right lateral ventricle, and approximately 6mm of subfalcine herniation to the left. No evidence of acute hemorrhage. Following administration of intravenous contrast, a 4.5 x 3.8 cm irregular, peripherally enhancing intra-axial lesion is identified within this region, consistent with a neoplastic process or abscess.

MRI_Brain_without_and_with_gadolinium.Findings: A large (approximately 4.5 x 3.8 x 4.0 cm) intra-axial lesion is identified in the right fronto-parietal lobe. The lesion exhibits heterogeneous signal intensity on T1 and T2-weighted images, with marked surrounding vasogenic edema (hyperintense on T2/FLAIR sequences). Post-gadolinium T1-weighted images demonstrate thick, irregular peripheral enhancement with central areas of non-enhancement, suggestive of necrosis. Significant mass effect is noted with compression of the right lateral ventricle, effacement of sulci, and 7mm of subfalcine herniation. Findings are highly suspicious for a high-grade glioma (e.g., glioblastoma) or a solitary metastasis. No other lesions identified.

Chest_X-ray_PA_and_Lateral.Findings: Lungs are clear. No pleural effusion or consolidation. Cardiac silhouette is within normal limits. No obvious mass lesion identified. Bones appear normal.

Other_Procedures.Lumbar_Puncture_Status: Deferred and contraindicated due to imaging findings of a space-occupying lesion with significant mass effect and midline shift, which poses a high risk of cerebral herniation.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Cerebral Tumour (likely high-grade glioma or metastasis)

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess, investigate, and diagnose a patient presenting with a progressively worsening headache and subtle neurological signs.

Patient_Actor.History: Sarah presents with a headache that began approximately 2 weeks ago. Initially, she attributed it to stress from a new project at work. The headache has progressively worsened and is now described as constant, severe (8/10), diffuse, and throbbing. It is worse in the mornings upon waking, and exacerbated by bending forward, coughing, or straining. Over-the-counter analgesics (paracetamol, ibuprofen) provide minimal relief. For the past 3 days, she has experienced nausea, and has vomited twice in the last 24 hours. She also reports intermittent transient blurring of vision, especially when reading. She started a combined oral contraceptive pill (OCP) 3 months ago for contraception. About 3 weeks ago, she had a self-limiting episode of gastroenteritis with vomiting and diarrhea for 2 days, during which she felt quite dehydrated.

Secondary_Symptoms: Headache worse on waking and with Valsalva-like maneuvers

Current_Medications: Combined oral contraceptive pill (started 3 months ago)

Patient_Actor.Family_History: Mother diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) at age 45. Father has hypertension. No family history of migraines or neurological disorders.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Works as a marketing executive, reports high stress levels recently. Non-smoker. Drinks 2-3 units of alcohol socially on weekends. Denies illicit drug use. Lives with her partner.

Review_of_Systems.Neurological: Besides headache and visual blurring, denies seizures, syncope, frank weakness, numbness, tingling, or speech difficulties. Denies aura preceding headaches.
Review_of_Systems.HEENT: Denies fever, chills, neck stiffness, photophobia (though bright light bothers her due to headache severity). Denies recent head trauma. Denies sinus pain, congestion, or rhinorrhea. Denies ear pain or discharge.
Review_of_Systems.Gastrointestinal: Nausea and vomiting as described. Denies abdominal pain or change in bowel habit (other than recent gastroenteritis).

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Appears uncomfortable and fatigued, lying still on the examination couch. Well-nourished.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert, oriented to person, place, and time (GCS 15/15). Speech is clear and coherent.

Cranial_Nerves.CN_II: Visual acuity grossly intact (patient reports transient blurring subjectively). Visual fields full to confrontation. Fundoscopy reveals bilateral papilledema with venous engorgement and blurring of optic disc margins.
Cranial_Nerves.CN_III_IV_VI: Pupils equal (3mm), round, and reactive to light and accommodation. Mild impairment of abduction of the right eye (right lateral rectus weakness, CN VI palsy). Full range of other extraocular movements.
Cranial_Nerves.CN_V: Facial sensation intact in all three divisions bilaterally. Motor V (muscles of mastication) power normal.
Cranial_Nerves.CN_VII: Facial movements symmetrical, no facial droop.
Cranial_Nerves.CN_VIII: Hearing grossly intact to whispered voice.
Cranial_Nerves.CN_IX_X: Uvula midline, symmetrical palate elevation. Gag reflex present.
Cranial_Nerves.CN_XI: Shoulder shrug and head turn against resistance normal.

Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Subtle pronator drift on the right upper limb. Power otherwise 5/5 in all four limbs. Normal muscle bulk and tone. No fasciculations.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception in all four limbs.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes 2+ and symmetrical throughout. Plantar responses downgoing bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Function: Finger-nose-finger and heel-to-shin tests performed well bilaterally. No dysmetria or intention tremor.
Neurological_Examination.Gait: Observed to be slightly cautious but no ataxia. Romberg's test negative.
Neurological_Examination.Meningeal_Signs: Neck supple. Kernig's sign negative. Brudzinski's sign negative.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Cardiovascular_Examination: Normal S1 and S2, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Peripheral pulses present and symmetrical.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Respiratory_Examination: Chest clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes or crackles.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Abdominal_Examination: Soft, non-tender, non-distended. Bowel sounds present and normal. No hepatosplenomegaly.

Blood_Tests.Full_Blood_Count: WBC 11.5 x 10^9/L (neutrophils 70%), Hb 13.5 g/dL, Platelets 250 x 10^9/L.
Blood_Tests.Urea_and_Electrolytes: Sodium 138 mmol/L, Potassium 4.0 mmol/L, Urea 5.2 mmol/L, Creatinine 70 µmol/L. (All within normal limits)
Blood_Tests.Liver_Function_Tests: ALT 25 U/L, AST 30 U/L, ALP 80 U/L, Bilirubin 10 µmol/L. (All within normal limits)

CT_Brain_Non_Contrast.Findings: Subtle hyperdensity noted within the posterior aspect of the superior sagittal sinus ('dense triangle sign' or 'cord sign'). No evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage, mass effect, or hydrocephalus. Ventricles are normal in size. Grey-white matter differentiation is preserved.

MRI_Brain_with_MR_Venography_MRV.Findings_MRI: T2-weighted and FLAIR images show bilateral parasagittal areas of vasogenic edema, more prominent on the right. Small focus of restricted diffusion in the right parietal lobe suggestive of early venous infarction. Susceptibility Weighted Imaging (SWI) demonstrates blooming within the superior sagittal sinus and right transverse sinus. Post-contrast T1 images show lack of flow-related enhancement in these sinuses.
MRI_Brain_with_MR_Venography_MRV.Findings_MRV: Extensive filling defects identified in the superior sagittal sinus, extending into the right transverse sinus and right sigmoid sinus, consistent with extensive cerebral venous thrombosis.

CSF_Analysis.Glucose: 3.5 mmol/L (Serum glucose 5.0 mmol/L; CSF/Serum ratio 0.7 - Normal).

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Cerebral Venous Thrombosis (Superior Sagittal Sinus, Right Transverse Sinus, and Right Sigmoid Sinus)

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose a 45-year-old female presenting with chronic headaches, focusing on potential musculoskeletal and neurological causes.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient reports a gradual onset of headaches over the past 6 months. Initially intermittent, they now occur 3-4 times per week. She describes the headache as a dull, aching pain, typically starting in the suboccipital region and radiating to the ipsilateral temple and sometimes over the eye. The pain is often worse towards the end of the workday or after prolonged periods of sitting at her computer. She also notes associated neck stiffness and intermittent aching in her right shoulder. Over-the-counter analgesics like ibuprofen provide only partial and temporary relief. She denies any recent significant head or neck trauma. She mentions noticing occasional visual 'floaters' recently but denies true blurred vision, diplopia, or visual field loss.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Headache, predominantly right-sided, originating from neck
Secondary_Symptoms: Occasional mild, non-vertiginous dizziness with severe headaches

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Mild scoliosis diagnosed in adolescence, no active treatment. Cholecystectomy 10 years ago. No history of migraines, hypertension, or known neurological disorders.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Works as an accountant, involves prolonged computer use. Non-smoker. Drinks 1-2 glasses of wine on weekends. Reports increased work-related stress recently due to an upcoming audit.
Medications: Ibuprofen 400mg PRN for headaches (up to 2-3 times on bad days)

Review_of_Systems.General: Denies fever, chills, night sweats, or unexplained weight loss. Reports some fatigue, attributed to poor sleep due to headaches.
Review_of_Systems.Neurological: Headache as described. Denies focal weakness, true numbness or persistent paresthesias in limbs (other than occasional shoulder ache). Denies seizures, syncope, dysphasia, or dysphagia. Denies true vertigo or ataxia. Visual floaters as mentioned, but no blurring, diplopia, or visual field defects.
Review_of_Systems.HEENT: Denies photophobia or phonophobia as primary features of headache (though prefers quiet when pain is severe). Denies eye pain, redness, or discharge. Denies sinus pain, pressure, nasal discharge, or ear pain. Denies jaw claudication or significant scalp tenderness (other than muscular).
Review_of_Systems.Respiratory: Denies cough or shortness of breath.
Review_of_Systems.Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea or vomiting, except very occasionally when headache is extremely severe.
Review_of_Systems.Musculoskeletal: Neck stiffness and shoulder ache as described. Denies other joint pain or swelling.

General_Examination.Appearance: Alert, oriented x4, cooperative. Appears in mild discomfort.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert and oriented, speech clear and fluent.
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: II-XII intact. Visual acuity 6/6 bilaterally (Snellen). Visual fields full to confrontation. Fundoscopy: Optic discs sharp, no papilledema, normal vasculature. Pupils equal, round, reactive to light and accommodation (PERRLA). Extraocular movements intact, no nystagmus. Facial sensation and power symmetrical. Hearing grossly intact.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Tone normal throughout. Power 5/5 in all major muscle groups, upper and lower limbs. No pronator drift.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception in all four limbs.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Biceps, triceps, brachioradialis, patellar, and Achilles reflexes 2+ and symmetrical. Plantar responses downgoing bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Coordination: Finger-nose-finger and heel-to-shin tests performed well. No dysdiadochokinesia.
Neurological_Examination.Gait: Normal gait, able to tandem walk.

Musculoskeletal_Examination_Cervical_Spi.Inspection: Mild forward head posture. No visible swelling, erythema, or gross deformity of the cervical spine. Shoulders appear level.
Musculoskeletal_Examination_Cervical_Spi.Palpation: Moderate tenderness to palpation over the right C2-C3 and C3-C4 facet joints. Palpation of the right suboccipital muscles and upper trapezius reproduces the patient's typical headache and right-sided neck pain. Multiple trigger points noted in the right upper trapezius and levator scapulae muscles. No tenderness over temporal arteries. No midline spinous process tenderness to deep palpation.

Range_of_Motion_Cervical_Spine.Extension: Limited by 20%, reproduces posterior neck pain.
Range_of_Motion_Cervical_Spine.Rotation_Right: Limited by 30%, reproduces right-sided headache and neck pain.

Special_Tests_Cervical_Spine.Cervical_Flexion_Rotation_Test: Positive on the right (reproduction of familiar headache and restriction of rotation when neck is fully flexed and rotated to the right).

Head_and_Neck_Examination_Other.TMJ: No clicks, tenderness, or limitation of opening.
Head_and_Neck_Examination_Other.Sinuses: Non-tender to palpation over frontal and maxillary sinuses.

X_ray_Cervical_Spine_AP_Lateral_Odontoid.Findings: Mild straightening of the normal cervical lordosis. Minor degenerative changes with small osteophytes at C4-C5 and C5-C6 levels. No acute fracture, subluxation, or instability. Vertebral body heights maintained.

MRI_Brain_without_contrast.Reason_for_ordering: To rule out intracranial pathology given chronicity of headaches and reported visual floaters.
MRI_Brain_without_contrast.Findings: Normal brain parenchyma, ventricular system, and cisterns. No evidence of mass lesion, hemorrhage, infarction, hydrocephalus, or signs suggestive of idiopathic intracranial hypertension. Normal appearance of major intracranial vessels. No abnormal enhancement post-contrast (if contrast was given, but here specified 'without').

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Cervicogenic Headache secondary to Cervical Dysfunction (likely C2-C3 facet joint and related muscular involvement)

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose a patient presenting with chronic headaches and recent onset of neck pain and arm paraesthesia.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 4-month history of headaches, primarily located in the occipital region, described as a dull ache that sometimes radiates to the vertex and right shoulder. Initially, she attributed it to stress and eye strain from her work as an accountant. Over-the-counter analgesics (ibuprofen, paracetamol) provide only minimal and temporary relief. Over the past month, she has also developed intermittent neck stiffness and a tingling sensation in her right thumb and index finger, especially after prolonged periods of sitting at her computer or looking down.

Secondary_Symptoms: Tingling in right thumb and index finger
Headache worsened by neck movement and prolonged sitting
Occasional radiation of pain to right shoulder

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Hypertension, well-controlled with medication. Osteoarthritis in knees diagnosed 5 years ago. No history of migraine, head trauma, or malignancy.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Works as an accountant, spends long hours at a desk. Non-smoker. Drinks 2-3 glasses of wine per week. Enjoys gardening.
Patient_Actor.Family_History: Mother had hypertension and osteoarthritis. Father died of myocardial infarction at 72. No family history of neurological disorders or severe headaches.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Reports occasional, mild dizziness when turning head quickly, but denies true vertigo. Denies fever, chills, night sweats, or unexplained weight loss. No visual disturbances (blurring, diplopia, photophobia), no phonophobia. No nausea or vomiting. No focal weakness in limbs, other than subjective feeling of slight clumsiness in right hand recently. No seizures or loss of consciousness. No bowel or bladder dysfunction. Denies jaw claudication or scalp tenderness. Denies recent infections or travel.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Appears well, in mild discomfort. Alert and oriented x4.
Physical_Examination_Findings.HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic. Pupils equal, round, reactive to light and accommodation. Extraocular movements intact. Fundoscopy normal, no papilledema. No sinus tenderness. Oropharynx clear. Temporal arteries non-tender, normal pulsation.

Neck_Examination.Inspection: No visible deformities, swelling, or erythema.
Neck_Examination.Palpation: Tenderness over the lower cervical paraspinal muscles and right C5-C6 facet joints. No palpable lymphadenopathy.
Neck_Examination.Range_of_Motion: Reduced and painful cervical extension and right lateral rotation. Mild crepitus noted with movement. Flexion and left lateral rotation mildly restricted.
Neck_Examination.Special_Tests: Spurling's test positive on the right, reproducing tingling in the right thumb and index finger. Lhermitte's sign negative.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Cardiovascular_Examination: Regular rate and rhythm, S1 S2 normal, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Carotid pulses 2+ bilaterally, no bruits.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Respiratory_Examination: Chest clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Abdominal_Examination: Soft, non-tender, non-distended. Normoactive bowel sounds. No hepatosplenomegaly.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert, oriented x4, attention and concentration intact.
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: II-XII grossly intact. Visual fields full to confrontation. Facial sensation and movement symmetrical.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Power 5/5 in all major muscle groups bilaterally, except for subtle right wrist extension weakness (4+/5) and right biceps (4+/5). Normal tone. No muscle atrophy.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Reduced light touch and pinprick sensation over the right thumb and index finger (C6 dermatome). Intact sensation elsewhere. Vibration and proprioception intact.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Biceps reflex 1+ on the right, 2+ on the left. Triceps and brachioradialis reflexes 2+ bilaterally. Patellar and Achilles reflexes 2+ bilaterally. Plantar responses flexor bilaterally. Hoffman's sign negative.
Neurological_Examination.Coordination: Finger-nose-finger and heel-to-shin tests normal bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Gait: Normal, steady gait. Able to tandem walk.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Musculoskeletal_Examination_Other: Full range of motion in shoulders, elbows, wrists, and hands bilaterally, apart from pain on resisted right wrist extension. No signs of active inflammation in other joints.

Blood_Tests.Erythrocyte_Sedimentation_Rate_ESR: 25 mm/hr (Normal: <20 mm/hr for age/sex; mildly elevated)
Blood_Tests.Comprehensive_Metabolic_Panel_CMP: Within normal limits (Sodium, Potassium, Chloride, CO2, BUN, Creatinine, Glucose, Calcium, Total Protein, Albumin, ALP, ALT, AST, Bilirubin)

CT_Brain_without_contrast.Reason_for_ordering: Initial workup for persistent headache to rule out acute intracranial pathology.
CT_Brain_without_contrast.Findings: No acute intracranial hemorrhage, mass effect, or evidence of hydrocephalus. Age-appropriate parenchymal appearance. Sinuses clear.

XRay_Cervical_Spine_AP_Lateral_Oblique_v.Reason_for_ordering: Evaluate for bony abnormalities given neck pain, radicular symptoms, and positive Spurling's test.
XRay_Cervical_Spine_AP_Lateral_Oblique_v.Findings: Moderate degenerative changes noted, most prominent at C5-C6 and C6-C7 levels. Findings include disc space narrowing, anterior and posterior osteophyte formation, and facet joint arthropathy. No acute fracture or dislocation. Neural foramina appear narrowed on oblique views, particularly C5-C6 on the right.

MRI_Cervical_Spine_without_contrast.Reason_for_ordering: Further evaluate extent of degenerative changes and nerve root impingement given radicular symptoms and X-ray findings.
MRI_Cervical_Spine_without_contrast.Findings: Multi-level degenerative disc disease. At C5-C6, there is a broad-based right paracentral disc protrusion combined with uncovertebral and facet joint osteophytes, resulting in moderate right neural foraminal stenosis and impingement upon the exiting C6 nerve root. Mild central canal stenosis at this level without cord signal abnormality. Mild degenerative changes at other cervical levels. Spinal cord appears normal in signal intensity.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Cervical spondylosis with right C6 radiculopathy and cervicogenic headache

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose a patient presenting with chronic unilateral headache, considering musculoskeletal and neurological differential diagnoses.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 3-month history of a persistent, right-sided headache. She describes the onset as gradual, without a specific trigger event, but notes it has become more frequent and bothersome. She works as an administrative assistant, spending 8-10 hours daily at a computer, and mentions her home office setup isn't ideal since transitioning to remote work. She recalls a minor whiplash injury from a low-speed car accident about 10 years ago, which resolved with physiotherapy at the time. The current headache is different from any she has experienced before.

Secondary_Symptoms: Pain radiating from neck to right temple and behind the right eye
Headache worsened by prolonged sitting and specific neck movements (e.g., looking right)
Occasional non-specific lightheadedness, not true vertigo
Mild nausea when headache is severe
Occasional difficulty focusing vision when headache is at its peak

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Whiplash injury (10 years ago, resolved). Mild hypertension, well-controlled with medication. No history of migraines or other significant neurological conditions.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Works as an administrative assistant (desk-based, prolonged computer use). Non-smoker. Drinks 2-3 units of alcohol per week. Reports increased stress due to work demands. Regular walker for exercise, but has reduced activity due to neck discomfort.
Medications: Occasional ibuprofen 400mg for headache (provides partial relief for a few hours)
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Reports pain as dull and aching, rated 4-7/10. Denies fever, chills, night sweats, or unexplained weight loss. No aura, photophobia, or phonophobia. No thunderclap onset. No seizures, syncope, weakness, or persistent numbness in limbs. No difficulty swallowing or speaking. Denies jaw claudication or scalp tenderness over temporal arteries. No recent infections. No symptoms of sinusitis (facial pressure, purulent nasal discharge). Bowel and bladder habits unchanged.

General_Examination.Appearance: Appears comfortable at rest, but winces with certain neck movements.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert and oriented to time, place, and person. Speech is clear and fluent.
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: II-XII intact. Pupils equal, round, reactive to light and accommodation. Visual fields full to confrontation. Fundoscopy shows sharp optic discs, no papilledema. Extraocular movements intact.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Power 5/5 in all four limbs. Tone normal. No pronator drift.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception in all four limbs. No specific dermatomal sensory loss noted.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Biceps, triceps, brachioradialis, patellar, and Achilles reflexes 2+ and symmetrical.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Function: Finger-nose and heel-shin tests performed well. Gait normal, no ataxia.
Neurological_Examination.Meningeal_Signs: No neck rigidity on passive flexion (though active movement limited by pain). Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs negative.

Musculoskeletal_Examination.Cervical_Spine_Inspection: No visible deformities or swelling. Mild forward head posture noted.
Musculoskeletal_Examination.Cervical_Spine_Palpation: Tenderness to palpation over the right C2-C3 facet joint region and right suboccipital muscles. Palpable muscle spasm in the right upper trapezius and levator scapulae.
Musculoskeletal_Examination.Cervical_Spine_Range_of_Motion: Active range of motion reduced: Right rotation limited to 40 degrees (left 70 degrees), right lateral flexion limited to 20 degrees (left 40 degrees). Flexion and extension mildly restricted at end-range. Reproduction of typical right-sided headache with sustained right rotation and right lateral flexion.
Musculoskeletal_Examination.Provocative_Tests: Positive cervical flexion-rotation test on the right (reproduction of headache). Manual pressure over the tender right C2/C3 facet joint reproduces the patient's typical headache.
Musculoskeletal_Examination.Shoulder_Examination: Full range of motion, no tenderness (pertinent negative to rule out referred shoulder pain as primary source).

Other_Examinations.TMJ_Examination: No tenderness, clicking, or crepitus. Full range of motion.
Other_Examinations.Temporal_Artery_Palpation: Non-tender, normal pulse, no nodules (pertinent negative for GCA).

MRI_Brain_with_and_without_contrast.Findings: Normal brain parenchyma. No evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage, infarct, mass lesion, hydrocephalus, or abnormal enhancement. Ventricles and sulci are normal for age. Paranasal sinuses are clear.

Cervical_Spine_X-ray_AP_Lateral_Odontoid.Findings: Mild degenerative changes noted at C4-C5 and C5-C6 levels, including small anterior osteophytes and slight reduction in disc height. Straightening of the normal cervical lordosis. No acute fracture, subluxation, or destructive bony lesion identified.

MRI_Cervical_Spine_without_contrast.Findings: Mild degenerative disc disease at C4-C5 and C5-C6 as seen on X-ray, without significant central canal stenosis or neural foraminal narrowing. Mild facet joint arthropathy noted at the right C2-C3 level. No evidence of cord compression, syrinx, or significant nerve root impingement. Paraspinal soft tissues unremarkable.
